1508753-a.folder: Fifth Avenue - 38th Street - 38th Street, west side, Manhattan, NY
1508753-a.title: Fifth Avenue - 38th Street - 38th Street, west side

1557876.folder: 424 Fifth Avenue - West 38th Street, Manhattan, NY
1557876.title: 424 Fifth Avenue - West 38th Street

708620f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., east side, north from East 37th to 38th Streets. The
empty lot is at the N.E. corner of 37th Street.
About 1910.

708622f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, north from 38th Street.
Small brick house to right of tall white building is Wendel House.
Bristol Hotel is right background.
1907.
Brown Brothers, Photographer.

708623f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, at, adjoining and north of the N. W. corner of West 38th Street, showing the private residences that formerly stood here. This site in 1940 is occupied by the commercial structure housing Lord & Taylors.
Note the curbstone advertisement reading "For Congress
Wm. F. Dodge".
About 1880's ?
American Studio, photo
87 Nassau St., N. Y. C.
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS UNENOWN

708624f-a.text:
North on east side, of Fifth Avenue from 38th Street.
Union League Club at left centre.
Temple Emanu-El at extreme left.
1907.
Brown Brothers, Photographer.

708625f-a.text:
(1)
North on Fifth Avenue from 38th Street.
Note Union League Club at right, now demolished.
February 23, 1931.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.
(2)
North on east s ide of Fifth Avenue, from south of 38th Street, showing razing of Union League Club.
May 15, 1932.
P.. Sperr,Photographer.
(3)
North on Fifth Avenue from south of 38tth Street.
Union League 9lub is marked Y.
It was built in 1883-84, and was demolished in 1932.
It was a staunch Tepublican Club.
March 10, 1929.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

708626f-a.text:
North on Fifth Avenue from 38th Street.
March 22, 1935.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

708627f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., west side, north from and including West 38th Street, as viewed from an elevated point midway between 37th and 38th Streets. Note at the N.W. corner of 39th Street the 4-story Wendel House that has been replaced by a low business structure. Several blocks northward appears another structure that has been replaced; No. 500 Fifth Ave., at the N.W. corner of 42nd Street (shown with sign thereon). The apparent gap between these is occupied by the New York Public Library, which is receded
from the normal building line.
About 1928.

708628f-a.text:
The block bet. 39th E 40th Streets is to be demolished. Republic National Bank home office, formerly the Knox Building is to remain. A forty to fifty storey bldg is planned for the site.
Earl Christian, NNPL photographer
EE

712484f-a.text:
10-8 East 38th Street, south side, between Madison and Fifth Avenues. This picture is dated tentatively; it may have been taken two years earlier when No. 10 was also temporarily vacant. No. B, the boarded-up house, is the residence of Mrs. Jacob Wendell.
1V11.

712485f.text:
38th Street, south side, west from Fifth Avenue
May 2, 1907.
Brown Brothers.

712486f.text:
38th Street, north side, west from Fifth Avenue.
May 15, 1907.
Brown Brothers.

712487f-a.text:
38th Street, north side, east from Fifth Avenue.
May 15, 1907.
Brown Brothers.

712488f.text:
38th Street, south side, east from Fifth Avenue. Nos. 2 and 18 are two-story stables. No. 12 is the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Scribner. At Madison Avenue may be seen the old Havemeyer mansion at the S.W. corner and South Church (Dutch. Reformed) on the S.E. Corner.
May 2, 1907.
Brown Brothers.

712489f-a.text:
29, 27 West 38th Street, north side, between Sixth and Fifth
Avenues.
1910 or 1911.

712490f-a.text:
38, 40, 42-46, 48-56 West 38th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. No. 38, with the cafeteria on the ground floor, is quite new; No. 4O is the last of a group of five
brownstone residences.
About 1922.
Apeda Studios.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

730130f-a.text:
General View Midtown Manhattan, East 40's: View 1 shows buildings under construction in the East 40's, as seen from East 48th Street near Lexington Avenue. View 2 shows the skyscraper group in the east 40's. From left to right they are: New York Central (backaround), 10 East 40th Street, the Lincoln, Chrysler (not finished), Chanin, News, and Combustion Engineering (extreme right) Buildings, seen from Broadway and
34th Street.
View 3 shows the same group of skyscrapers, seen from Fifth
Avenue and 38th Street.
View 1: September 5, 1928
Views 2,3: 1930
P. L. Sperr
730130f-a.title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - East 40s.
